title: "You deserved to lose your baby": Sick message 'sent to couple who cancelled carpet cleaner because of miscarriage'
text:
Dean and Charlotte Coutts were left devastated after losing what would have been their first baby (Photo: Dean Coutts / SWNS.com) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A couple who cancelled a carpet-cleaning job because they suffered a miscarriage claim they were told by the firm: "You deserved to lose your baby." 
Distressed Dean and Charlotte Coutts booked a session with Clean Carpets Plymouth but called it off when she was rushed to hospital. 
Two weeks after losing what would have been their first child they were stunned to receive an £85 invoice for the job - but refused to pay. 
They claim they were then subjected to a string of "aggressive" and "threatening" messages taunting them about the loss of their baby and demanding more money. 
Dean, 26, of Plymouth, Devon, claims a representative of the firm even told him on the phone: "You deserved to lose your baby." The couple say they have been threatened with small claims court action (Photo: Dean Coutts / SWNS.com) Read More Mum shares heartbreaking experience of ectopic pregnancy in desperate warning to other mothers 
Police are now investigating a possible offence under the Malicious Communications Act. 
Dean claims the manager also told him "the best thing has happened" to their baby and that the couple aren't "worthy of being parents". 
The company declined to comment when presented with the accusations. 
But Dean has published a stack of more than 30 text messages that allegedly show the company boss adding up to £1,000 to the couple's invoice. 
Dean said the whole experience had added to their distress at an already devastating time. 
He said: "We didn't even cancel the job at the last minute - we booked the appointment and within 10 minutes of taking it said we could not do it any more. A Facebook exchange between Charlotte and the company in which she is labelled "not the brightest" (Photo: SWNS.com) Read More Call The Midwife’s Laura Main talks Shelagh Turner's cliffhanger, after Susanna Reid admits crying three times during latest episode 
"He said it's fine then a few weeks later we got messages. They were disgusting and aggressive. 
"He was saying we owe him money and he would take us to court. My wife is just in bits, it's terrible for me to see. She's not in the best place." 
Police have now been called in to investigate the complaint. 
Mr Coutts, who works as a fabricator, added: "It has not been easy. 
"The trouble is, we went through the miscarriage and this had made it all worse. 
"It's pushed me too far - my missus is in bits." 
Mrs Coutts, 22, who was 12-weeks pregnant when she lost the baby, has also written about their experience on Facebook and her post has been shared more than 2,000 times. Read More 
The messages sent to them demand money and taunt the couple by rapidly putting the bill up. 
One message also reads: "See you in court." 
While another says: "Not the brightest are you Charlotte," and another calls the couple "self-employed time wasters". 
Mrs Coutts said: "Unfortunately I couldn't (re-book) as I had just lost my baby and got out of hospital a few days prior. 
"It wasn't a priority at that time. 
"So following that, they told me to read their terms and conditions that wasn't stated when I originally spoke to them saying I owe them the full amount of £85. Police are investigating a possible breach of the Malicious Communications Act (Photo: Getty) Read More Mum who had £22,000 of failed IVF and miscarriage finally has miracle twins after finding surrogate on Facebook 
"Because I refused to pay it, they are taking us to small claims court. 
"All I have had is harassment and evil messages telling me that I owe them more money because I was begging them to stop messaging me." 
When contacted, the manager of Clean Carpets Plymouth, Ben Harbour, said he did not wish to comment on any of the accusations made by the couple. 
Devon and Cornwall Police said in a statement: "We are currently investigating an incident that could fall foul of the Malicious Communications Act. Enquiries are underway." Like us on Facebook
